Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2008 06:53PM - edited Nov 18, 2008 06:53PM by jaepinkroses Here's Johns post...just posted less than an hour ago today on the thread mentioned above: 53 minutes ago AlaskaDeb wrote: All, Thanks for all the Great Vibes!  Deb had Chemo yesterday and we spoke to Dr. Kelly.  He would have liked to seen more progress (Duh wouldn't we all!)  but says the fact that she is progressing is very good.  He also did not feel this would be a permanent thing.   Today, she seems to be feeling good for the day after chemo, so we went for our walk.  She did great but I decided it was time to head back as I was getting cold! (It dropped below 0 last night & was about 8 degrees at walk time (1:30pm).  Time to get out my winter boots & wear gloves.  I also got a copy of deb's blood work numbers.   She is due for a week off next week but I wanted to make sure things were not getting too low.  I have not kept up on these things as much as I probably should since when I scanned the numbers a curious number jumped out at me.  I never knew that they actually rated "BUN"(s?).  This begs the question. How do you improve your "BUN"(s?)/"CREAT"(ive?) ratio???????????  Is this a dance move?   Oh well, I'll just keep walking.......as Deb alway says, John's Ignorance is Bliss.    Also, Deb's appetite came back the last couple of days. She's been eating very well.   This afternoon, she had just finished her lunch. A sandwich, milk, her favorite chips, fresh veggies, and some orange slices....Well rounded I thought.  I then gave her some more chocolate milk & went into the other room to change the laundry.  I came back a minute later & she had one chipmunk cheek.  A week or so ago she was not swallowing without being told so I naturally told her to swallow.   She refused!  So I told her to open her mouth & there was the plastic lid to the milk jug. I paniced & got her to spit it out.  Naturally,  I gave her more to eat!   All in all though,  I think it's a great sign!  Blessings to all & Thanks again for the Prayers & Well Wishes! John

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2007 06:45AM jaepinkroses wrote: My husband had vertigo several years ago...he was prescribed Meclizine and it worked ...Meclizine is also available over the counter in an anti motion-sickness medicine called Bonine.  Hope you feel better soon.
Posts.Title: Holy crap -- vertigo.... kimmytoo kimf

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2007 11:30AM - edited Nov 15, 2007 11:33AM by jaepinkroses Bimmer and Diane, I'm very sorry you're having to deal with such severe pain.  I read where you said "I explained that they screw with you every 30 minutes day and night in the hospital and that being in the hospital is a fate worse than death itself. Then I told her how Diane wants to die at home in her own bed, with her family around her, and not in a hospital." and it really touched me, because that is also what we feared about my sister ending up in the hospital.  Not all hospitals are like that. I know your situation may not quite be to the same point that my sister's was, but having recently been through my sister's hospitalization at the end of her life (Oct 20-27, 2007), I think that your "fate" largely depends on the individual, which hospital, its staff and maybe how proactive your family is.   At my hometown hospital, from her entry to the emergency room ...to the very last day...every single nurse and doctor were gentle, caring, and strove to keep her as comfortable and pain free as possible. My mom, dad, daughter and myself were with my sister mostly around the clock for 6 days and saw every nurse and doctor.  They maintained excellent care with as little disturbance as they could, explained every procedure - to her and to us, were responsive when we  asked questions or made suggestions, and since we had at least two family members sitting right with her 24/7, towards the end of things, other than checking her every two hours or so during the day and about three times quietly during the night, they mostly allowed us to just call them when we needed them.  And when we called, we had immediate response every time via a walkie-talkie type device and never had to wait more than 1 or 2 minutes before we saw a human. We had a fold out sofa in the room that made into a bed for our use at night, as well as a recliner chair that would lay flat. Her original plan was also to die at home, but as things turned out I don't think we could have kept her as pain free or comfortable that way and we were not restricted in who could be with her at any time day or night at the hospital.  (We actually had so many family members come during the day the first few days, that the hospital offered to move her to a larger room to accomodate us, but we declined and I will admit I've never heard of any hospital doing that before).  In a horrid situation, at least for her, being in the hospital was not an issue that made things worse. My point is, she was as painfree as possible and surrounded by her family even though at a hospital and we as her family, were supported by the hospital staffs expertise at all hours of the day and night. This is of course a personal decision, and I don't know where you are located, or what your hospital choices are, but I hope you won't completely rule out the option of a hospital if Dianes pain gets really severe again at home.  Looking back now, it was a good solution for my sister and our family. Gentle hugs to you both.  judy
Posts.Title: Very advanced B.C. III: Battling the beast Bimmer JoyRebecca

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2007 08:51PM jaepinkroses wrote: My sister has triple neg bc. Original diagnosis Dec 2004, IDC and DCIS 4.5 cm tumor, grade III. 1 node of 17 pos. Original treatment was left mast, then Adriamycin/Cytoxin.  Supposedly cancer free after  treatment. Then Dec 12 2005 Liver mets "too numerous to count" found. Largest 7 cm.   Immediately started chemo again. Chemo so far has been:      1. Adriamycin/Cytoxin  (initial chemo) Since mets found:      2. Taxotere      3. Xeloda      4. Gemzar      5. Navelbine      6. Abraxane      7. Taxol/Carboplatin/Avastin (still on this - since Sept 2006...once weekly for three weeks then one week off)  She had substantial shrinkage of all tumors till all were down to 1 cm or less with Taxol/Carboplatin/Avastin, and then stayed stable until chemo break from May 2007-mid July 2007 (break was forced because her body was too toxic from extended chemo.)  Scans in July 07 showed substantial progression and new tumors up to 5.5 cm but still liver only.  July 27, 2007 restarted Taxol/Carboplatin/Avastin and Sept 2007 latest scan results show 30% shrinkage of most tumors and no more new ones. BC still "only" found in liver.  Chemo is hitting her even harder now than before the break.  And her onc hasn't come up with a "next" option yet in case Taxol/Carboplatin/Avastin stops working (as all the others eventually did) - he's researching and he's been great, but says she's tried most everything he knows to try that might work. She's also been told she's not a good candidate for RFA or Chemoemobilization because of the number and position of her tumors. (she would feel so much better just knowing there is a next waiting in the wings as I'm sure you can imagine) If anyone can suggest something to try next, please post it or PM me.  Her onc is actively looking for something and is open to suggestions.  Thanks to you all.  judy

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2007 06:28AM jaepinkroses wrote: I'm soooo sorry to hear of the loss of your wife.  I lost my only sister last week (Oct 27th) to this disease too. She was only 46, my best friend and her memorial service was today. I've mostly "lurked" here too... gathering info since I really didn't feel I had much to contribute, but have really appreciated this site for the incredibly helpful people and accurate information available here. This is a horribly unfair and ugly disease.  You have my deepest sympathy.  judy
Posts.Title: Another Angel among us this week - Bev34 LuAnnH kimmie39

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2008 01:32AM - edited Oct 17, 2008 11:49PM by jaepinkroses I'm sooooo sorry for your loss.  We lost my sister last October to bc and as a family were devastated by her illness and her loss and we miss her every day.   So here we are now near the end of the first year without her...and have struggled too...trying to find a way to get through family holidays, birthday's and other gatherings without too many tears and give the kids special days too....We had a really hard time at first and spent the first Thanksgiving after her death together with a lot of tears...and it was very hard.....  I think what helped us a lot to get through the next holiday's was finding a way to laugh together again ....and it sounds weird but we did that by playing Nintendo Wii games together.  My family has always been a very close one, and my sister and I had always gotten together with our parents and my husband and kids and now their families or spouses and even In-laws for most holidays and family birthday parties... usually at my parents house.  My sister loved to play games and even while she was fighting cancer she was the driving force organizing us all to play cards or board games for HOURS at each and every family gathering.......so we're sure she wouldn't want us to sit around crying now, but at first it was hard not to...and we just couldn't bring ourselves to play the same old card games etc that we'd always done as a group with her ...and when we tried....that empty chair just loomed at the table...and it just wasn't fun.  Then that first Christmas my husband and I gave our daughter and her soon to be husband a Wii Sports game system as their Christmas gift...(it had been on my daughters wish list for a year and we knew nothing about Wii, but were unexpectedly able to get one, so decided to surprise her with something she really wanted for a change)  and as an unexpected bonus we discovered what we now call our "Wii therapy" and you can make fun if you want...but it has really helped us to do something new together ....and most importantly to me....it's helped my parents because Mom spent that first Christmas day ..a day she'd been dreading and didn't know how she'd get through....  taking turns playing Wii games, learning Wii bowling and laughing and Dad joined in too. (at that time the Wii was completely new to all of us ...none of the rest of us were video game players at all,  but EVERYBODY in our family now likes the Wii) .... Anyway, we ended up spending most of that Christmas afternoon with ten of us taking turns playing the different sports games that came with the Wii set, laughing uproariously at ourselves and each other...and for the first time were also able to talk about Debbie a little without crying.... first about how she would have loved this game and then about other things too.  Most every family birthday & holiday since then.....at some point of the day we set up the Wii and play something together and it has helped distract us and get us through difficult times.  The Wii always makes us laugh .......and laughter is something that had been hard to come by for a long time....My husband and I now have our own Wii game system, and so do my mom & dad.  It's been worth every penny to get some laughter flowing again....and it gets us moving too.   This is just something that helps us...I really hope you find a way to get through special days too. ((hugs)) judy
Posts.Title: christmas and special days mpieterse VickiG

Posts.Title: I love Shelli because....... geeta75 rue2u

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2008 01:50AM - edited Jul 10, 2008 10:54AM by jaepinkroses Am hoping your mom's problem is resolved quickly and (((hugs))) to both of you. ....Don't want to scare you, but I also agree with the others that your mom needs to see a doctor as soon as possible to get this checked out and Monday is too long to wait.  I lost my only sister at 46 last October to liver and kidney failure related to BC chemo treatments she was receiving for liver mets.   If your mom is in the beginnings of liver failure it can be very serious and can happen very quickly.  My sisters initial symptoms started just one day after a "routine" chemo treatment (same drugs she'd been receiving for over 7 months - taxol, carboplatin, and avastin) and were only a general feeling of being unwell and lethargic, back pain and then the abdominal swelling began that we later found out was caused by fluid buildup (ascites). There are treatments that can help but unfortunately hers was not able to be reversed and she was gone within a week.  My personal recommendation based on that is don't wait...convince her to go and be seen now even if that means a trip to the ER.  Wishing you all the best.  Judy

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2007 11:27PM jaepinkroses wrote: Shelli fought this disease with enormous grace and courage.  Her love for her family and caring for others on these boards showed hugely in her posts.  I've so admired her up beat attitude and cheerfulness of her writing, and that in spite of everything that was happening to her, she still took the time to come here to try to help others on a regular basis.   She made a difference, helped many, and will be remembered.   To Shelli's family, please accept my heartfelt sympathy.  Judy

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2007 01:31AM jaepinkroses wrote: LuAnn, I can feel your pain.  My son (a young Marine reservist) spent most of 2005 in Iraq. He left for Iraq the same month my sister had her first bc surgery, leaving his fiance (now his wife) and her twin little boys here at home... Thankfully he made it back safe & sound and has not had to return.  His enlistment is finished on April 18th 2008 and we're counting the days and hoping that his unit doesn't get deployed anywhere again before that.  We were able hear from him semi regularly while he was there though. On average we had some sort of contact with him every other week or so...sometimes weekly, sometimes not for three weeks at a time.   Most units had internet access of one sort or another available to them whenever they were in camp or on base and were able to email at least once every couple of weeks if they wanted (or had time to stand in line for their turn on the computers).  We sent him phone cards and he was able to make short calls home too if at a base location. (need to be sure the cards match whatever phone system is being used where he is, as it can vary).  The Marine Corps also has a system called Motomail, where we could register for free at a website, then were able to send email to his specific "address" and the message would be printed in Iraq at the base nearest him and was usually delivered to him as regular written mail within 24 to 36 hours.  I don't know if the other branches of the service have something similar to that but it might be something to ask him about. The website (http://www.motomail.org/) does say that Navy,Army & Air force personnel co-located with Marines are eligible to receive motomail too.  We could send up to two messages a day that way if we wanted and it was great for keeping him updated and in touch with things at home, was much faster than regular mail, free, and allowed us to condense things during the quick phone calls he would make, since he would already know most of what was going on at home.  We also sent care packages to him via his domestic military address and I got really good at packing a lot of heavy stuff into those small flat rate boxes you can get from the post office (no charge for the box till you mail it and they now cost $8.95 no matter what they weigh). Hopefully your son will be at a location where he will have some kind of access and will be able to contact those at home sometimes too.  It helps to know they're really okay.  (My son was mostly based at Al Asad air base in Al Ambar Province but was often sent off base on "missions"). I was a nervous wreck while he was over there and can barely imagine you dealing with this as well as your own medical situation. It's very hard having a child of any age over there.  I wish you all the very best.  judy
Posts.Title: Please keep my son in your prayers LuAnnH judyr
